title: webR in Quarto HTML Documents
text:
Each class session has an interactive lesson that you will work through after doing the readings and watching the lecture. These lessons are a central part of the class—they will teach you how to use {ggplot2} and other packages in the tidyverse to create beautiful and truthful visualizations with R.
Interactive code sections look like this. Make changes in the text box and click on the green “Run Code” button to see the results. Sometimes there will be a tab with a hint or solution.






Your turn



Modify the code here to show the relationship between health and wealth for 2002 instead of 2007.

 Interactive editor Hint



Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.


Hint: You’ll want to change something in the code that creates gapminder_filtered. The text in the subtitle won’t change automatically, so you’ll want to edit that too.





If you’re curious how this works, each interactive code section uses the amazing {quarto-webr} package to run R directly in your browser.

title: Week 02 Research Methods & Statistics
Week 02 Research Methods & Statistics
text:
Fin
Thanks for checking out the demo! Let’s head back to the documentation portal.

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
Data Visualization Beyond Graphs
More than Just Charts [noun] /ˈdeɪtə vɪʒuəlɪˈzeɪʃən/

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
1. Data as Stories
Concept:
Data visualization isn’t just about numbers; it’s about telling a compelling story. The visual elements should guide the viewer through a narrative—showing change over time, revealing relationships, or highlighting key insights.
Application:
Case studies or reports where data unfolds in a logical, easy-to-follow sequence, such as telling the story of a community’s health or an individual’s progress.
Example:
An interactive webpage showing the impact of social media on mental health through a narrative of personal experiences and trends.

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
2. Infographics
Concept:
Infographics combine text, visuals, and data to create a highly accessible, single-view communication tool. They are visually engaging, often using illustrations, icons, and small amounts of data to convey key points at a glance.
Application:
Ideal for social media, brochures, or posters where quick digestion of information is needed. Frequently used in public campaigns, marketing, and education.
Example:
An infographic explaining the psychology of sleep, showing how sleep cycles work and tips to improve sleep habits.

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
3. Animations
Concept:
Animations bring data to life by adding movement, showing how data evolves over time or revealing complex processes step-by-step. They are effective in capturing attention and illustrating dynamic changes.
Application:
Excellent for presentations, video content, or interactive dashboards. Can be used in education to break down complex processes (e.g., brain activity) or in marketing to show trends over time.
Example:
An animated chart showing the rise of global temperatures over decades, or an animation walking through the steps of a psychological experiment.

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
4. Dashboards
Concept:
Dashboards provide a comprehensive, real-time view of data, often integrating multiple graphs and charts into one interface. They allow users to interact with the data, filter information, and explore different aspects on demand.
Application:
Useful in business, healthcare, or education where decision-makers need up-to-date, actionable insights. Dashboards can provide an overview of research data, employee performance, or patient metrics.
Example:
A live dashboard tracking the results of a clinical trial, showing participant progress, side effects, and key outcome measures.

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
5. Data-Driven Art
Concept:
Data-driven art turns data into creative visual expressions, where aesthetics and meaning are equally important. It communicates complex ideas through artistic mediums, helping people emotionally connect with the data.
Application:
Useful in public exhibitions, museums, or campaigns designed to evoke emotional responses. Can be particularly impactful when the goal is to inspire action or reflection.
Example:
A visual installation representing the world’s most polluted cities, where the intensity of color and shape corresponds to pollution levels.

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
6. Interactive Visualizations
Concept:
Interactive visualizations allow the audience to explore the data themselves. Users can hover over elements, click to reveal additional information, and adjust parameters in real time to see how different variables influence outcomes.
Application:
Excellent for websites, educational tools, and data journalism. This method is perfect for exploring complex datasets where users need control over what they want to see.
Example:
A web tool where users can explore the effects of different factors (e.g., age, gender, education) on job satisfaction.

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
7. Maps and Geospatial Visualizations
Concept:
Data visualized on maps can be incredibly powerful, especially when geographic context is essential to the story. These visuals can show patterns across different locations, reveal relationships between data and place, and help identify regional trends.
Application:
Used in public health (tracking disease outbreaks), environmental research (tracking deforestation), and social science (mapping crime rates).
Example:
A heatmap showing the spread of a disease outbreak, highlighting areas of high infection rates over time.

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
8. Narrated Data
Concept:
Narrated data takes storytelling a step further by adding voiceovers or text to guide the viewer through the visualization, ensuring that key points are not missed and context is clearly explained.
Application:
Ideal for educational content, presentations, and documentaries where understanding the deeper meaning behind the data is essential.
Example:
A video presentation explaining the impact of climate change, with data visualizations narrated by an expert who explains each trend.

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
Introduction to Data Visualization

What is Data Visualization?

Definition: The graphical representation of data to find insights, patterns, and trends.
Importance: Simplifying complex data, making research more accessible, and aiding in decision-making.

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
Introduction to Data Visualization

Why is it Important for Psychologists?

For Self: Making sense of information.
Outwards: Presenting results to a wider audience (academics, professionals, the public).

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
The Goals of Data Visualization

Communication of Information

Making data accessible, clear, and engaging.
Translating raw numbers into understandable narratives.

Pattern Recognition

Identifying trends, outliers, and relationships.
Supporting statistical analysis by visually highlighting key elements.

Exploration

Using visuals to explore and understand datasets during the research process.

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
Types of Data

Categorical Data

Nominal (e.g., types of therapy, animal species)
Ordinal (e.g., Likert scales, levels of education)

Continuous Data

Interval (e.g., temperature, time of day)
Ratio (e.g., height, reaction time)

Discrete vs Continuous

The difference between countable categories and measurements with infinite possible values.

title: Data Visualisation 1
section: Common Types of Graphs and When to Use Them
text:
Common Types of Graphs and When to Use Them

Bar Charts

Best for comparing discrete categories.
Example: Comparing the number of participants in different experimental groups.

Histograms

Useful for visualizing the distribution of continuous data.
Example: Showing the frequency distribution of test scores.

Pie Charts

Use for displaying proportions of a whole, though less frequently used in scientific contexts.

Line Graphs

Great for showing trends over time or continuous data relationships.
Example: Reaction time changes over time.

Scatterplots

Ideal for representing relationships between two continuous variables.
Example: Relationship between stress levels and performance.

Boxplots

Excellent for summarizing the distribution, central tendency, and variability of continuous data.

Heatmaps and Density Plots

Useful for visualizing large, complex datasets, or relationships between multiple variables.

Violin Plots

Combines boxplot and density information to visualize data distribution.

title: Data Visualisation 1
section: The Many Ways to Convey Information 1
text:
The Many Ways to Convey Information 1

Tables

When to use: Presenting precise numerical data or categorical comparisons.

Infographics

A visual story: Combining graphs, icons, and minimal text to tell a narrative (good for public dissemination).

title: Data Visualisation 1
section: The Many Ways to Convey Information 2
text:
The Many Ways to Convey Information 2

Interactive Visualizations

Dynamic data representations, useful for exploring and filtering datasets in real-time (tools like Shiny or Tableau).

Dashboards

Overviewing multiple aspects of data in one space for decision-making, often used in applied settings.

title: Data Visualisation 1
section: The Many Ways to Convey Information 3
text:
The Many Ways to Convey Information 3

Flowcharts and Diagrams

Best for depicting processes or causal relationships.

Presenting Visuals in Scientific Reports

Adapting visuals to APA standards (formatting, labeling, figure legends).

title: Data Visualisation 1
section: Design Principles for Effective Data Visualizations
text:
Design Principles for Effective Data Visualizations

Clarity and Simplicity

Avoid unnecessary elements (e.g., chartjunk, 3D effects).
Focus on the key message and make the visualization intuitive to interpret.

Consistency

Use consistent colors, fonts, and labels across different graphs.

Labeling and Annotations

Clear axis titles, units, and legends to make the graph self-explanatory.

Color Choices

Consider color blindness (red-green blindness common) and use color schemes that enhance readability.

Appropriate Scale

Avoid misleading visuals by ensuring that scales are not exaggerated or compressed.

Hierarchy and Focus

Guide the viewer’s attention to the most important parts of the graph (using size, bolding, or contrasting colors).

Telling a Story

Visuals should flow logically and lead the reader through the narrative of your data.

title: Data Visualisation 1
section: How to Choose the Right Graph for Your Data
text:
How to Choose the Right Graph for Your Data

Understanding Your Audience

Tailor complexity based on who is consuming the data (public, peers, experts).

Data-Driven Decision Making

Choose the graph based on the data structure and the key message you want to convey.

Avoid Common Pitfalls

Misleading graphs (incorrect scales, truncated axes) can misinform rather than clarify.
Overcomplicating simple messages with too many visual elements or excessive detail.

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
Psychological Aspects of Data Visualization

Cognitive Load

Minimizing mental effort required to interpret visuals.

Gestalt Principles of Perception

How humans perceive visual elements (e.g., proximity, similarity, closure) and how to leverage these in visual design.

Emotional Impact of Visuals

Using visual design to invoke emotions (e.g., empathy, urgency), particularly in health or social psychology data.

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
Examples and Case Studies

Good vs Bad Visualizations

Comparing effective vs poorly designed graphs.
Examples from psychological research where data visualizations impacted understanding.

Interactive Exercise

Students create their own data visualization using sample datasets (e.g., reaction times, Likert scale responses).

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
Conclusion

Recap of key points: Visualization enhances comprehension, facilitates communication, and uncovers hidden patterns in data.
Encouragement: Practice visualizing data in R or Excel using real datasets.

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:

Dr. Gordon Wright

text:

Qualitative Research (3 weeks) with Hillary

Lecture, Labs, Data Skills, Application.

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:

Lecture slides are not lectures. Lectures are not lecture slides.
Introduce myself.

Should I introduce myself?

Any other advice?

Experts, added value content.

Should I make it funny? Honest? Intellectual? Geeky?
Aspirational, motivational, inspirational?

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
Welcome to University!

You’ve had an exciting first week.
The big question of Well-being:

What is it?
How do you measure it?
How do we increase it?

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
Positive Psychology

Using the power of your mind to achieve positive things.
And now, you’ve got me.

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
Introduction

I’ll take these first two lectures, labs, and data skills sessions.
We’ll explore life outcomes, well-being, success, happiness, and Positive Psychology.
We’ll dive into Positive Research Methods.

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
The Big Setup

One day, you’ll want to change a mind, capture interest, persuade, convince, or motivate.
It could be an idea, a product, a pitch, or even a truth.
I want you to be ready for that moment.
Practice now on ideas and data that aren’t life-changing… yet.

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
A World of Ideas

The world is your repertoire.
This is a psychology module, but let’s avoid talking about psychology today.
Let’s avoid numbers too!
And most importantly, let’s avoid being boring.

title: Data Visualisation 1
section: Standing on the Shoulders of Giants
text:
Standing on the Shoulders of Giants

Who said that?

[Pause for class participation]

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
Decision Making

What do I want to communicate?
What’s the best way to communicate that?

Is it risky?

Should I talk, show, demonstrate?
Should I pretend to be an expert or show my failures?

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
This Week & Next: Data Visualisation

Data Visualisation I & II.
Did I inspire wonder?

What if I had chosen a different title?

Truth, Beauty, and Power
Seeing is Believing: The Power of Data Visualization in Psychology
From Data to Drama: The Art of Psychological Storytelling

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
End Visualisation

People don’t like to be shown where they are; they like to see the destination.
Disneyland: “15 miles” vs “Only 15 minutes!”
Shampoo: “For Frizzy, Dry Hair” vs “Smooth n’ Sleek”
Are you derivative, boring, ‘grey’ or will you Think Different?

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
Positive Research Methods

Marcus Aurelius: “Master your mind, accept your fate, and act with virtue.”
Aristotle: “Live a balanced life guided by reason, virtue, and the pursuit of flourishing.”
Jagger: “You can’t always get what you want, but sometimes you get what you need.”

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
Dream Big

Do you have a dream?
Do you need a dream?

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
Why Visualize Data?

Visuals help us perceive patterns and relationships between variables.
In psychology, this is critical when studying associations like:

Age and cognition
Stress and health

A well-designed graph can uncover insights missed by numerical summaries alone.

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
Cognitive Bias and Visualization

Graphs tap into human visual perception: how we process shapes, contrasts, and relationships.
But be cautious! Our perception can also mislead:

Outliers can skew interpretations.
Complex designs (like 3D graphs) can distort reality.

Example: Anscombe’s Quartet — same statistics, but radically different scatterplots.

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
Visual Tasks in Psychology

In psychology, we often ask questions like:

Is there a pattern?
Is there a correlation?

Scatterplots, bar charts, and line graphs help us visually decode relationships faster than raw data.

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
Designing Honest Graphs

The aim is to present data truthfully:

Avoid chartjunk or misleading embellishments.
Keep the focus on the data, not the decoration.

In psychology, we need clarity to avoid misleading conclusions about human behavior and cognition.

title: Data Visualisation 1
text:
Perception and Human Cognition

Our minds tend to group visual data (Gestalt principles).

This can help but also mislead.

Example: Stacked bar charts can obscure individual trends within groups.

Be mindful of what you’re trying to communicate.

title: Data Visualisation 1
section: Plato’s Triad: The True, The Good, and The Beautiful
text:
Plato’s Triad: The True, The Good, and The Beautiful
Plato believed in the intrinsic connection between truth, goodness, and beauty — a concept that has influenced Western thought for centuries.
For Plato, these three qualities are inseparable in the realm of Forms.
The truth is inherently good, and what is good is also inherently beautiful.
Thus, if something is false, it cannot be truly beautiful or good.

title: Psychology of Deception: Web Exercises
text:
This is a Web Exercise template created by the psychology teaching team at the University of Glasgow, based on ideas from Software Carpentry. This template shows how instructors can easily create interactive web documents that students can use in self-guided learning.
The {webexercises} package provides a number of functions that you use in inline R code or through code chunk options to create HTML widgets (text boxes, pull down menus, buttons that reveal hidden content). Examples are given below. Render this file to HTML to see how it works.
NOTE: To use the widgets in the compiled HTML file, you need to have a JavaScript-enabled browser.

title: Psychology of Deception: Web Exercises
text:
Example Questions

Fill-In-The-Blanks (fitb())
Create fill-in-the-blank questions using fitb(), providing the answer as the first argument.

2 + 2 is 

You can also create these questions dynamically, using variables from your R session.

The square root of 25 is: 

The blanks are case-sensitive; if you don’t care about case, use the argument ignore_case = TRUE.

What is the letter after D? 

If you want to ignore differences in whitespace use, use the argument ignore_ws = TRUE (which is the default) and include spaces in your answer anywhere they could be acceptable.

How do you load the tidyverse package? 

You can set more than one possible correct answer by setting the answers as a vector.

Type a vowel: 

You can use regular expressions to test answers against more complex rules.

Type any 3 letters: 



Multiple Choice (mcq())

“Never gonna give you up, never gonna: let you goturn you downrun awaylet you down”
“I bless the rainsguess it rainssense the rain down in Africa” -Toto



True or False (torf())

True or False? You can permute values in a vector using sample(). TRUEFALSE



Longer MCQs (longmcq())
When your answers are very long, sometimes a drop-down select box gets formatted oddly. You can use longmcq() to deal with this. Since the answers are long, It’s probably best to set up the options inside an R chunk with echo=FALSE.
What is a p-value?

 the probability that the null hypothesis is true the probability of the observed, or more extreme, data, under the assumption that the null-hypothesis is true the probability of making an error in your conclusion

What is true about a 95% confidence interval of the mean?

 if you repeated the process many times, 95% of intervals calculated in this way contain the true mean there is a 95% probability that the true mean lies within this range 95% of the data fall within this range

title: Psychology of Deception: Web Exercises
text:
Checked sections
Create sections with the class webex-check to add a button that hides feedback until it is pressed. Add the class webex-box to draw a box around the section (or use your own styles).

I am going to learn a lot: TRUEFALSE
What is a p-value?

 the probability that the null hypothesis is true the probability of the observed, or more extreme, data, under the assumption that the null-hypothesis is true the probability of making an error in your conclusion

title: Psychology of Deception: Web Exercises
text:
Hidden solutions and hints
You can fence off a solution area that will be hidden behind a button using hide() before the solution and unhide() after, each as inline R code. Pass the text you want to appear on the button to the hide() function.
If the solution is a code chunk, instead of using hide() and unhide(), simply set the webex.hide chunk option to TRUE, or set it to the string you wish to display on the button.
Recreate the scatterplot below, using the built-in cars dataset.











I need a hint

See the documentation for plot() (?plot)





Click here to see the solution

plot(cars$speed, cars$dist)


This set of exercises will test your knowledge about various aspects of deception in psychology. Answer the questions to check your understanding of key concepts, theories, and research findings in this area.

title: Psychology of Deception: Web Exercises
text:
Fill-In-The-Blanks

The tendency for people to believe they are less likely to be deceived than others is known as the  to deception.
In deception research, the  is an actor who works with the experimenter to deceive the actual participant.
The  is a genuine smile that involves both the mouth and the eyes, making it harder to fake in deceptive situations.

title: Psychology of Deception: Web Exercises
text:
Multiple Choice

Which of the following is NOT typically considered a reliable indicator of deception?

Increased blinkingReduced hand gesturesLack of eye contactIncreased speech errors

The theory that proposes that lying is more cognitively demanding than telling the truth is called:

Interpersonal Deception TheoryCognitive Load TheoryFour-Factor TheorySelf-Presentation Theory

In a typical deception study, who is usually unaware of the true nature of the experiment?

ParticipantExperimenterConfederateResearch Assistant

title: Psychology of Deception: Web Exercises
text:
True or False

Polygraph tests are highly accurate and widely accepted in scientific communities as reliable lie detectors. TRUEFALSE
People are generally better at detecting lies told by strangers than by those close to them. TRUEFALSE
Microexpressions are brief, involuntary facial expressions that can potentially reveal concealed emotions in deceptive situations. TRUEFALSE

title: Psychology of Deception: Web Exercises
text:
Longer MCQs
Which of the following best describes the “Truth-Default Theory” in deception research?

 The theory that humans are naturally inclined to always tell the truth The theory that humans tend to believe others are telling the truth unless given reason to think otherwise The theory that truth-telling is easier and requires less cognitive effort than lying The theory that cultural norms universally prioritize truthfulness over deception

What is the primary focus of Interpersonal Deception Theory (IDT)?

 The neurological processes involved in creating and maintaining a lie The dynamic interaction between the deceiver and the target of deception The psychological motivations that drive individuals to engage in deceptive behavior The cultural variations in perceptions and acceptance of deceptive practices

title: Psychology of Deception: Web Exercises
text:
Checked sections

Research suggests that detecting deception is:
Easy for most peopleOnly possible with specialized trainingDifficult, with accuracy rates often only slightly above chanceImpossible without technological aids
Explain why detecting deception is challenging for most people:


Click for explanation

Detecting deception is challenging for several reasons:

Many common beliefs about deception cues (e.g., lack of eye contact) are not reliable indicators.
Liars often strategically control their behavior to appear truthful.
Individual differences in baseline behavior make it hard to identify deviations.
The cognitive load of trying to detect lies can impair judgment.
Confirmation bias can lead people to interpret ambiguous cues in line with their expectations.

title: Psychology of Deception: Web Exercises
text:
Hidden solutions and hints
A researcher wants to study how cognitive load affects lying behavior. Describe a potential experimental design to investigate this.


I need a hint

Consider how you might manipulate cognitive load (e.g., through a secondary task) and measure lying behavior. Think about what control conditions you might need.




Click here to see a possible experimental design

# Possible Experimental Design:

# Participants: 100 adults randomly assigned to two groups (50 each)
# 
# Procedure:
# 1. All participants are asked to lie about a recent experience
# 
# 2. Experimental group: 
#    - Must count backwards from 100 by 7s while lying (high cognitive load)
# 
# 3. Control group:
#    - Simply lie without additional task (normal cognitive load)
# 
# 4. Measure dependent variables:
#    - Speech hesitations
#    - Speech rate
#    - Amount of detail provided
#    - Perceived believability (rated by independent judges)
# 
# 5. Compare measures between groups to assess the effect of cognitive load on lying behavior

# This design allows us to isolate the effect of increased cognitive load on various aspects of lying behavior.


This set of exercises covers various aspects of deception psychology, including theories, research methods, and key findings. It utilizes different question types to engage learners and test their understanding of the subject matter.
